summary: Email correspondence between defense attorneys and a prosecutor regarding a stipulation agreement about admitting a partial trial transcript as evidence. The emails discuss revisions to the wording of the stipulation, labeling it as 'Defendant's Trial Exhibit A', and logistics for signing and delivering the document.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Appears to be the sender/recipient of emails coordinating the stipulation agreement and requesting a clean version to be signed.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Sternheim
persons.context: Defense attorney communicating about the stipulation, indicating it works for the defense and discussing signing logistics.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Defense attorney copied on the email correspondence regarding the stipulation agreement.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney copied on the email chain discussing the stipulation.

connections.description: Communicating directly about the terms and logistics of a legal stipulation agreement, indicating a professional legal relationship.
Both are defense attorneys copied on the same correspondence and working together on the stipulation matter.
Both are attorneys copied on the same legal correspondence regarding a stipulation.

events.title: Stipulation Email Finalization
events.description: Christian Everdell sends a clean version of a stipulation agreement, now labeled 'Defendant's Trial Exhibit A', and arranges for it to be signed and delivered.

events.title: Stipulation Language Proposal
events.description: An Assistant United States Attorney proposes specific language for a stipulation regarding a partial trial transcript from February 26.

keyFacts: The correspondence concerns a stipulation to admit a 'true and accurate copy of the transcript of one witness's trial testimony, but not the full trial transcript, given on February 26...' as evidence.
The stipulation is to be labeled 'Defendant's Trial Exhibit A'.
The emails show coordination between defense attorneys (Sternheim, Menninger) and a prosecutor (likely Everdell) on evidentiary matters.
The document is part of legal preparations, indicating an ongoing legal process related to trial testimony.
